definitions: shorten word phrase or text by omitting letters or words
examples: Please abbreviate 'Doctor' to 'Dr.' in the document
The editor abbreviated the lengthy manuscript for publication

definitions: take someone away illegally by force or deception typically for ransom
examples: The criminals planned to abduct the wealthy businessman
Aliens abducted humans in the science fiction movie

definitions: regard with disgust and hatred feeling extreme repugnance toward something
examples: Most people abhor violence against innocent civilians
She abhors dishonesty in any form whatsoever

definitions: accept or act in accordance with rule decision or recommendation
tolerate or bear something unpleasant continuing despite difficulty
examples: Citizens must abide by the laws of their country
All players must abide by the referee's decisions
I cannot abide rudeness in my classroom
She couldn't abide living in such noisy conditions

definitions: formally put an end to system practice or institution permanently
examples: Many countries have abolished the death penalty completely
The new government promised to abolish unfair taxes

definitions: leave hurriedly and secretly typically to avoid detection or arrest
examples: The treasurer absconded with the company's funds
The prisoner absconded from the minimum security facility

definitions: set or declare someone free from blame guilt or responsibility
examples: The court absolved him of all criminal charges
The priest absolved the penitent of their sins

definitions: restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something deliberately avoiding participation
examples: Many people abstain from alcohol for health reasons
Three members abstained from voting on the proposal

definitions: assent or agree to demand request or treaty often reluctantly
assume office or position especially becoming monarch or leader
examples: The company finally acceded to the workers' demands
The government acceded to the peace treaty terms
Prince Charles will accede to the throne eventually
She acceded to the presidency after the election

definitions: make more noticeable or prominent drawing attention to particular feature
examples: Makeup can accentuate your best facial features naturally
The tight dress accentuates her slim figure beautifully

definitions: praise enthusiastically and publicly expressing strong approval or admiration
examples: Critics acclaimed her performance as the year's best
The novel was widely acclaimed by readers worldwide

definitions: become accustomed to new climate or conditions adapting gradually
examples: It takes time to acclimate to high altitude conditions
New employees need weeks to acclimate to company culture

definitions: approach and address someone boldly or aggressively often unexpectedly
examples: A stranger accosted me on the street asking for money
The angry customer accosted the manager about poor service

definitions: accumulate or receive payments or benefits over period of time
examples: Interest accrues daily on your savings account balance
Vacation days accrue based on years of employment

definitions: gather together or acquire increasing number or quantity over time
examples: Dust accumulates quickly on unused surfaces
She accumulated vast wealth through wise investments

definitions: make someone aware of or familiar with something or someone
examples: Let me acquaint you with our company policies
They acquainted themselves with local customs before traveling

definitions: accept something reluctantly but without protest giving silent consent
examples: She acquiesced to her parents' wishes about college
The board acquiesced in the CEO's decision reluctantly

definitions: cause machine or device to operate by mechanical or electrical means
cause someone to act in particular way motivating behavior
examples: The sensor actuates the automatic doors when approached
A small motor actuates the robotic arm precisely
Greed actuated his decision to betray his partners
What principles actuate your political beliefs

definitions: stick fast to surface or substance bonding physically together
believe in and follow practices or rules maintaining loyalty
examples: The tape won't adhere to wet or dirty surfaces
Glue makes paper adhere to the poster board
Students must adhere to the school dress code
We adhere strictly to safety protocols here

definitions: be next to and joined with sharing common boundary
examples: Their property adjoins the national park boundary
The kitchen adjoins the dining room perfectly

definitions: break off meeting or legal case with intention of resuming later
examples: The judge adjourned the trial until Monday morning
Let's adjourn this meeting and reconvene tomorrow

definitions: make formal judgment or decision about problem or disputed matter
examples: The court will adjudicate the dispute between neighbors
A panel of experts adjudicated the competition entries

definitions: warn or reprimand someone firmly about their behavior or actions
examples: The teacher admonished students for talking during the test
His mother admonished him to drive more carefully

definitions: make more beautiful or attractive by adding decorative elements
examples: Fresh flowers adorned every table at the wedding
She adorned herself with jewelry for the gala

definitions: render poorer in quality by adding another substance typically inferior
examples: Some vendors adulterate honey with corn syrup
The drug dealer adulterated cocaine with harmful substances

definitions: publicly recommend or support particular cause or policy speaking in favor
examples: She advocates for children's rights in developing countries
The senator advocates stricter gun control laws

definitions: officially attach or connect subsidiary group to larger organization
examples: The local club affiliated with the national organization
Many universities affiliate with nearby hospitals for training

definitions: stick fasten or attach something to something else physically
examples: Please affix your signature to the bottom of the form
Affix the stamp to the upper right corner

definitions: make problem injury or offense worse or more serious than before
annoy or exasperate someone especially persistently irritating them
examples: Scratching will only aggravate the mosquito bite
Cold weather aggravates her arthritis symptoms
His constant complaining aggravates everyone around him
Don't aggravate your sister while she's studying

definitions: form or group into class or cluster combining multiple elements
examples: The website aggregates news from various sources worldwide
Scientists aggregate data from multiple research studies

definitions: stir or shake something vigorously especially liquid mixing thoroughly
make someone troubled or nervous causing anxiety or concern
examples: Agitate the mixture before adding the next ingredient
The washing machine agitates clothes to clean them
The bad news agitated her for days afterward
Loud noises agitate the rescue animals

definitions: undergo great mental anguish through worrying about something excessively
examples: She agonized over the decision for several weeks
Parents agonize about their children's future constantly

definitions: cause someone to feel isolated or estranged from others
examples: His behavior alienated all his former friends
Don't alienate customers with poor service

definitions: place or arrange things in straight line adjusting position
give support to person organization or cause matching positions
examples: Align the wheels properly for smooth driving
The students aligned their desks in neat rows
The company aligned itself with environmental causes
Several nations aligned against the common threat

definitions: diminish or put at rest fear suspicion or worry reducing intensity
examples: The announcement did little to allay investor concerns
Her kind words allayed his fears about surgery

definitions: claim or assert that someone has done something illegal or wrong typically without proof
examples: The prosecution alleges that he stole company funds
Neighbors allege noise violations against the nightclub

definitions: make suffering deficiency or problem less severe reducing intensity
examples: This medication alleviates chronic pain effectively
The new program alleviates poverty in rural areas

definitions: distribute resources or duties for particular purpose assigning systematically
examples: The committee allocates funds to various departments annually
We need to allocate more time for this project

definitions: give or apportion something to someone as share or task
examples: Each speaker is allotted fifteen minutes for presentation
The teacher allotted specific tasks to each student

definitions: suggest or call attention to indirectly hinting without explicit mention
examples: The speaker alluded to recent political scandals
She alluded to her difficult childhood briefly

definitions: combine or unite to form one organization or structure merging together
examples: The two companies amalgamated to increase market share
Several small towns amalgamated into one municipality

definitions: gather together or accumulate large amount of something over time
examples: He amassed a fortune through real estate investments
The library amassed rare books over many decades

definitions: make surprise attack on someone from concealed position lying in wait
examples: Rebels ambushed the convoy on the mountain road
The photographers ambushed the celebrity outside her home

definitions: make something bad or unsatisfactory better improving conditions or situations
examples: New policies aim to ameliorate working conditions significantly
Exercise can ameliorate symptoms of depression naturally

definitions: make minor changes in text in order to make it fairer more accurate or more up-to-date
examples: Congress voted to amend the constitution last year
Please amend your report to include recent data

definitions: increase volume of sound especially using electrical equipment
add details to story or statement expanding and clarifying
examples: The microphone amplifies the speaker's voice clearly
This device amplifies weak radio signals effectively
Could you amplify your earlier statement about the incident
The author amplified her arguments in the second edition

definitions: surgically remove limb or other body part due to injury or disease
examples: Doctors had to amputate his leg after the accident
The surgeon amputated three fingers to stop infection spreading

definitions: bring to life or activity giving spirit or vigor to something
give motion to images creating illusion of movement in film
examples: Her enthusiasm animates every conversation she joins
The teacher's passion animates even boring subjects
Artists animate characters for movies and video games
The software animates still images smoothly

definitions: append or add as extra or subordinate part especially territory
examples: The country annexed neighboring territories after the war
They annexed a new wing to the hospital building

definitions: destroy utterly obliterate completely leaving nothing remaining of something
examples: The atomic bomb annihilated the entire city instantly
The home team annihilated their opponents forty to zero
